sen.j: くちこ（海鼠子、口子）は、ナマコの卵巣である。
sen.e: Kuchiko (written in Japanese as 海鼠子, 口子) is the ovary of a sea cucumber.
Kuchiko are the ovaries of sea cucumbers.

sen.e: Kuchiko are the ovaries of sea cucumbers.
It is also called "konoko".
They are also called "konoko".

sen.j: ナマコは厳冬の1月から3月になると産卵期を迎えて発達肥大した卵巣を持つようになり、それが口先にあることから「くちこ」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: During the harsh winter between January and March, the sea cucumbers enter the breeding season and their ovaries grow enlarged; since the ovary is found at the tip of the mouth ("kuchi" in Japanese) of a sea cucumber, it is called "kuchiko" (literally, "child in the mouth").

sen.j: 主な産地は能登半島周辺。
sen.e: Kuchiko is mainly produced in and around the Noto Peninsular.

sen.j: 一般的に三角形に平たく干したものが能登の高級珍味として親しまれている。
sen.e: Generally the kuchiko is dried in a flat triangle form and known as Noto's high-quality food with a delicate flavor.

sen.j: 干した姿が、三味線のばちに似ていることから、ばちことも呼ばれている。
sen.e: Since it resembles the plectrum of shamisen (a three-stringed Japanese banjo) when dried, it is also called "bachiko" (literally, "plectrum child").

sen.j: 何枚も重ねて干し上げるが、一枚作るのに十数キロのナマコが必要であるため、大変高価なものとなる（2008年現在、一枚数千円）。
sen.e: Ovaries are dried in layers, and over a dozen ovaries are required to produce a single sheet of kuchiko; thus the food is very expensive (several thousand yen per sheet, as of 2008).

sen.e: Kuchiko can be eaten by itself, or also by being placed in soup or warmed sake after being roasted.

sen.e: Usually, raw kuchiko is sold well as salted kuchiko that have been preserved in salt, but sometimes, the ovaries taken out of sea urchins are simply bottled and sold "raw".
